subject: unit test metrics
msgSnippet: I m unhappy about the small number of unit tests being written here and would like my colleagues to write more tests. Now I m considering creating a big
messageBody:
I'm unhappy about the small number of unit tests being written here and
would like my colleagues to write more tests. Now I'm considering
creating a big visible diagram showing the test coverage over time and
updating it every week to see if that will incite the team.

I'm thinking of creating a script that will count all public non-test
methods with more than 3 lines of code, and all test methods. The
diagram would show either the quotient (numberOfTestMethods divided by
numberOfBigProductionMethods) over time, or two graphs on top of each
other, one for each number over time (any suggestions which one would
be better?). I would update the diagram every week. The diagram will be
self explanatory, so I'm not intending to introduce it to the team or
explain my motivations unless asked.

Replacing the diagram after a while with a new one with different
dimensions (longer time period on the x-axis, higher number on the
y-axis) is probably confusing to observers of the diagram. So I'm
considering checking out older versions from our revision control
system to see how fast the numbers grow and creating a big enough
diagram from the start.

Does anyone have any thoughts or suggestions about doing this any
different? Is this even a good idea considering that there isn't an
absolute ideal number or quotient (like bug-count where the ideal would
be zero)?

Does anyone already have a script (in sed, Io, Python, or whatever)
that will do something like this for Java source code and JUnit tests
and is willing to share that with me?


Thanks,
Christian
